s.text: Fifth, you transfer your book from your PC's Rocket Library to your Rocket, which has 4 mb of memory (enough to hold 20 medium-length novels).
By contrast, the Rocket, which is made by a Silicon Valley start-up called NuvoMedia, is ergonomically sound, with the pleasing heft of a folded-over paperback.
Soon, they may do what a related device called the Audible can do, and actually read to you, either via sound files or text-to-voice software.
And because it doesn't need to be held open, you can read the Rocket one-handed.
I don't have a DVD player, an MP3 player, or a Palm Pilot.

One is the Softbook, which at $299 appears less expensive than the Rocket but actually costs more because you must commit to spending $479 on books over two years as part of the package.

You can buy Endless Referrals: Network Your Everyday Contacts Into Sales and Life Without Stress: The Far Eastern Antidote to Tension and Anxiety (which would seem to cancel each other out) but not Uncovering Clinton or The Ground Beneath Her Feet . Recent publications are gratuitously overpriced.
And I figured out how to download the full weekly text of Slate in one go by converting the Slate on Paper Microsoft Word file to the HTML format.
You buy books directly from Softbook and download them into the reader via a phone line.
Fifth, you transfer your book from your PC's Rocket Library to your Rocket, which has 4 mb of memory (enough to hold 20 medium-length novels).
